repnme.cdata!:
Tajikistan - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, with substantial institutional
            development impacts, being both performances rated
            satisfactory. Despite success, lessons suggest that while
            the ownership of the project resided with the President
            Administration, it varied among ministries and technical
            staff involved in the program. An effective vehicle would
            need to be instituted to involve mid-level, and technical
            level staff in the preparation and implementation of
            adjustment programs. Other lessons address a) the weak civil
            service, which affected the implementation of the program;
            2) economic decisions require more than the political will
            of the Government, rather a dual focus on assuring political
            ownership at the top, while supporting capacity building at
            the working level for an adequate implementation of reform;
            and, 3) an adjustment program is sustainable provided there
            is willingness to implement "next generation reforms".

docna.cdata!:
Tajikistan - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

Tajikistan - Second Structural

repnme.cdata!:
Tajikistan - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project : release of the second tranche - full compliance

abstracts.cdata!:
This report summarizes progress in the
            execution of the reform program and actions taken by the
            Government of the Republic of Tajikistan to meet the
            specific conditions for the release of the second tranche.
            The report concludes that the conditions for the release of
            the second tranche have been met.

repnme.cdata!:
Tajikistan - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project will support the first stages of reforms,
            particularly policy reforms to improve governance in
            general, and improve public sector management, service
            delivery, and budget/expenditure planning. It will also
            provide foreign exchange to maintain essential imports,
            boost international reserves, and provide non-inflationary
            financing for the budget. The Government's cross
            cutting reform program to support private sector
            development, includes policy actions in the financial
            sector, privatization, and enterprise reforms, and reforms
            in the infrastructure sector. The project will be beneficial
            for the establishment of a government budget audit office,
            public administration, and customs reforms, and for
            improving fiscal management, and developing a medium term
            expenditure framework. Nonetheless, risks include the
            deterioration of regional security due to political reasons;
            as well as weak implementation capacity, suggested by the
            lack of government understanding of the need for
            implementing sustained reforms, a fact which may not be
            guaranteed. Additionally, restructuring of external debt
            with major creditors, may imply risks for fiscal, and
            external sector sustainability, aggravated by the low level
            of reserves, which could adversely impact foreign exchange
            management. However, it is expected that the assurance of a
            sound macroeconomic framework, supported by the Poverty
            Reduction and Growth Facility from the International
            Monetary Fund, will mitigate those risks.
